key_title: Key to the species of Celmisia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria

source.author: Gray, M.; Given, D.
source.title: Celmisia
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Gray, M.; Given, D. (1999). Celmisia. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Upper surface of leaf with a thick or thin pellicle, sometimes deciduous in older leaves, the underside with short, compact or woolly tomentum; leaves rather stiff, persistent
Leaves without pellicle, both surfaces with persistant antrorse silky hairs, usually denser and silvery on the underside, velvety to the touch; leaves flat and soft- textured, renewed annually

Leaves less than 2 cm wide, or if wider, then with a thick, more or less persistent pellicle on upper surface; leaf underside with very short or more or less woolly tomentum; plants usually smaller and more slender than the preceding

Leaves usually more than 2 (up to 5) cm wide, stiff and flat, oblanceolate to narrowly oblanceolate or elliptic; pellicle of upper leaf surface very thin and weak, soon breaking up into fine, more or less deciduous webby fragments; leaf underside with a dense compact tomentum covered by a very thin silvery pellicle which soon breaks up into microscopic hair-like fragments, satiny to the touch; generally robust plants, sometimes forming tufts up to 1 m wide

Thin scaly rhizomes absent; rootstock branched and more or less woody, erect or ascending, or creeping and rooting to form often extensive patches; if tomentum of leaf underside short, with the midrib conspicuous, then tomentum hairs terete (under high magnification) and intermediate involucral bracts narrowly ovate- acuminate to narrowly triangular-acuminate

Tufted herbs with thin spreading scaly rhizomes; leaf underside with very short tomentum, the midrib usually raised and conspicuous; tomentum hairs flattened (under high magnification); intermediate involucral bracts narrowly triangular to narrowly triangular-subulate

Intermediate involucral bracts narrowly ovate- to narrowly triangular-acuminate, usually weakly tomentose at least distally, soon glabrescent and usually reddish-purple over most of the back, the margins densely woolly-fimbriate; leaves narrowly oblanceolate to narrowly elliptic or linear; pellicle soon rupturing beneath to reveal the short more or less woolly tomentum on the leaf underside, the raised midrib usually conspicuous; tomentum hairs terete (under high magnification)

Intermediate involucral bracts narrowly triangular to narrowly triangular-subulate, more or less tomentose (but usually glabrescent at least in the lower third), reddish-purple distally, the margins more or less fimbriate; leaves subulate to linear-subulate, sometimes expanded and narrowly oblanceolate; pellicle usually tardily rupturing beneath to reveal the long, woolly tomentum which fills the cavity on the leaf underside, usually obscuring the raised midrib; tomentum hairs flattened (under high magnification)
